headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, my name is Crystal and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Equity Residential Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. McKenna, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good morning, my name is Crystal and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Equity Residential Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. McKenna, you may begin your conference.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Crystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss Equity Residential's fourth quarter 2009 results and our 2010 outlook. Our featured speakers today are David Neithercut, our President and CEO; Mark Parrell, our Chief Financial Office
componenttext: Thanks, Crystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss Equity Residential's fourth quarter 2009 results and our 2010 outlook. Our featured speakers today are David Neithercut, our President and CEO; Mark Parrell, our Chief Financial Officer; and Fred Tuomi, our EVP of Property Management. David Santee, our EVP of Property Operations is also here with us for the Q&A.Certain matters discussed during this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Securities Law. These forward-looking statements are subject to certain economic risks and uncertainty. The company assumes no obligation to update or supplement these statements that become untrue because of subsequent events.Now I'll turn the call over to David.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marty. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our fourth quarter call. Well 2009 was certainly a very challenging year for the multifamily business. Really, we've never navigated through such uncertainty caused by such unprecedent
componenttext: Thank you, Marty. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our fourth quarter call. Well 2009 was certainly a very challenging year for the multifamily business. Really, we've never navigated through such uncertainty caused by such unprecedented job loss. Yet I've got to tell you, I could not been more pleased nor more proud of the way the Equity Residential team rose to the occasion, despite such challenging market conditions.For the year, same-store revenue results were down only 2.9%. The number's right on top of the mid-point of our original guidance that I've given to you all, one year ago. At our operating platform delivered strong same-store expense growth for the year, down 0.1%, and that really is a terrific outcome when compared to the comp year a year ago when expenses were up only 2.2%.Now thinking about this great expense control, I want to make something perfectly clear. This is not the result of reducing services to our residents and it's not the result of cutting back on how we care for our assets. And we know that because our customer service scores increased again in 2009, but it's the result of doing exactly what we have always been doing by using our scale, our concentration and technology to do it cheaper.So as evidenced by our guidance for 2010 in last night's release, we're expecting the picture to improve a little bit as the year progresses. Now in just a minute, Fred will go into a little bit more detail on what we're currently seeing and how we are thinking about revenues for 2010. But before he does that, I first want to say that we are already experiencing improving occupancy across many markets. When seasonally for this time of year, we would be expecting just the opposite to be happening. And while we still have above market leases that will need to be adjusted downward, our net effect of new lease rates are beginning to turn a little bit positive in many markets. And while our 2009 renewals were on average extended at flat to slightly negative levels, we'll beginning to see more renewals today with a very modest upward bias.Now this is all good news for the Apartment business, but I want to make sure that everyone understands, I'm not suggesting that we're experiencing any kind of sharp inflection here. I would rather say, we think we are at the beginning of a period of slowly and I do mean slowly improving fundamentals. But when job returns, if you add job growth to that picture, we believe that will quickly turn into one of the best operating periods in our history. So with that in mind, Fred, give everybody please a little color on how we are looking at revenues for 2010.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. So I'll give you a little more detail around our 2010 guidance for the same-store revenue. And this is based on what we're seeing on the ground today and the trends the we expect the business to follow over the coming year. So first, as
componenttext: Thank you, David. So I'll give you a little more detail around our 2010 guidance for the same-store revenue. And this is based on what we're seeing on the ground today and the trends the we expect the business to follow over the coming year. So first, as you know, our rental revenue is mostly impacted by four key drivers:  First, we have a continued roll down of those embedded leases that are currently above market rents, those have to roll down to net effective new lease rates; second is the rental rates achieved on our renewals; third is the resident turnover rate; and fourth is any change assumed in physical occupancy.So at a starting point, if you look at this year, assuming first, assuming no change in occupancy for the moment, our budgets would lead us to think that same-store rental revenue would decline by about a negative 2.9%. As that is just the mix of those first three things without an occupancy change. Then when we adjust for unexpected at least half point occupancy gains and some contribution from our other income categories, then we get to the total same-store revenue of down roughly 2%, which is right in the midpoint of our guidance range. So let's go to look a more detail in each one of those.First let's look at the net effective new lease rates. And if you remember, these are the current rents that we're achieving on brand new leases on a net effective basis, so new people moving in net effective rates. And as noted in previous quarters throughout 2009 is net effective new lease rates have remained relatively stable since January of last year. So had a big roll down late 2008, and we weren't sure what was going to happen in 2009 but we're very pleased with each quarter ticked off in '09. That those rents are pretty stable, up a little bit, down a little bit, but overall on a very narrow band. Let's stay right up to the end of 2009, but right at the end of fourth quarter, we noticed some pretty good seasonal pricing trends begin to develop.As we turned the quarter in late December and into January, we see a slight upward movement continuing in the first quarter of 2010. So after bouncing along a year-long bottom, we're seeing a modest but definitely noticeable upward trend in rates.Now the markets that are leading this upward trend include Boston; Washington D.C.; Denver, Colorado; and now South Florida. Boston is the strongest performer in this regard and rents are up about 3.3% from the same week a year ago. Now some markets are a little bit slower, they are lagging. Those that entered the recession later, kind of last to the end of the downturn such as Seattle and San Francisco. And then also those with deeper economic problems, larger scale job losses, maybe less chance for a recovery such as Phoenix, Arizona and the Inland Empire, it's is going to take longer. They're always going to lag in this recovery of rents. They will get there, it's just going to take a little while longer.Seattle is the farthest behind, and their net effective new lease rates are now about 9% below the same point a year ago. Now let's talk about the renewal fees. Obviously, the roll down to new pricing levels will continue through most of 2010. However, the downward trend as this process occurs is moderated, kind of a governor has put on it by the achieved renewal rates that you can get on those that do not move out.As we mentioned through 2009, we are very pleased. Initially surprised but very pleased that the net 12 month renewal rates on those people renewing, we were able to do that basically flat or only slightly down. That was a great kind of proof of consumer behavior, they are satisfied with their apartment, they are in there, they like us, they stay, they pay and they say good things about us.So the whole renewal process, our strategy starting with our pricing, our sales and communication of it, and we talk people through those change. Communicate, motivate but do not capitulate on those rents. So despite the reduced net effective new lease rates, as we turned into 2010, it has turned positive with an average increase of just under 1% up for our January renewals. And the February trend, we have already read about 39% for February, we're not done yet, so as another significant increase on this. As we get to the easier comp periods of the past plus our ability to sell renewals and negotiate tough, we are seeing a good lift on this renewal basis, which is a significant moderator to the roll down of rent rolls.So all about three of our core markets are now achieving positive renewal rate gains, led by the D.C. Maryland market at up 4.4%, and that's very healthy renewal rates in any market. However, in contrast, Seattle. Again, sorry to pick on Seattle. But as the rents were declining further, as we have noted earlier, they are averaging a 2.4% reduction in 12 months renewal rates in January. So we are seeing some write down in the renewal side piece as well in Seattle.Now coupled with this is resident turnover. And as you know, resident turnover has improved steadily over these past few years. We've been very happy with our resident retention movement. But for the 2010 budget baked into this guidance, we're assuming that it will remain flat for 2009.That brings us to the final driver of rental revenue, which is that of occupancy. As David mentioned, counter to seasonal expectations, leasing remained strong through late Q4 and well into January. Our occupancy has climbed of late and we're now at 94.6% as of yesterday. And it's the broad-based movement, many markets have experienced recent upmoves in occupancy right at a time when you think it might be moderating or soft.Some of these markets have made a move as great as 100 basis points. However, with stable or actually improving net effect of new lease rates. These improved markets like Los Angeles, which is now at 95% occupied, South Florida, 94.8% and Atlanta, Georgia even at 95.5%. And again we did not buy these occupancy gains. And this is the most encouraging signal to me to the start of 2010.So to recap our assumptions for the guidance for this year, our portfolio average net effect of new lease rates have turned upward and we believe this will continue, returning to a slight and modest growth by the years end. Renewal rates will remained positive and growth stronger throughout the year. The Resident turnover will hold steady at 61%.Put this into the rental revenue blender and you get 2.9% decline. However, offset favorably by a half point improvement in occupancy and a further contribution by other income, and again that yield been an approximate 2% decline in same-store revenues. For the entire year of 2010, it represents the midpoint of our guidance.So overall, we are very happy to see some positive signs out there in our system, but we have to remember, there's still a long way to go. Our platform and our people have served us extremely well in 2009. And we feel right now as we enter this year, we're very well positioned to capture the opportunities of a much awaited and much welcomed recovery. Thanks.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. Turning to transactions here after sitting on the side lines for quite a while, and not making any acquisitions due to uncertainty about property violations as well as more an important need to pour cash and manage the balance sheet, we've b
componenttext: Thanks, Fred. Turning to transactions here after sitting on the side lines for quite a while, and not making any acquisitions due to uncertainty about property violations as well as more an important need to pour cash and manage the balance sheet, we've become more active on the buy side over the last 90 days.Now as I said for quite some time, we would begin buying again when two things happen. Number one, we needed to become confident in our ability to fund our maturing debts in the normal course of business. And number two, we said we'd begin buying again when we began to see attractive pricing on good quality assets in core markets. Assets that we could acquire a discount replacement costs at good IRRs and which we thought we'd create good long-term value for our shareholders.We did acquire two assets in the fourth quarter of last year. But first, we discussed a little bit on our last earnings call in late October, and that was a high rise tower in the Pentagon City neighborhood of Arlington, Virginia. Built in 2004, we pro forma the 6.1% yield on that asset in our first year. The second acquisition in the fourth quarter of 2009 was Mosaic at Largo Station. That deal was in Maryland just east of the district near FedEx Field. That was completed in 2008, and was still in leased up when we acquired it and we'd pro forma there a stabilized yield in the high sixes.And more recently, thus far in 2010, we have acquired five additional assets. The two Macklowe assets, which we announced on Monday, which we're just extremely well located in premier multifamily assets. But in addition to those, we acquired a mid-rise property near the beach in Delamar, California which was built in 1998. We are going to do a repositioning on this asset, and we project it a year or a two yield of 6.7%.We've also acquired another high rise tower in Arlington, Virginia called Vista on Courthouse, that deal was built in 2008 and we pro forma on a 5.9% per share yield on that acquisition. We've also acquired just this week and closed on Tuesday, a mid-rise property in Seattle built in 2002 and we acquired that with a 6.6% cap rate.And of course, won a contract to acquire the third Macklowe asset, which will close no later than May 1. We're also pursuing a couple of additional deals, each of which we think are extremely well-located, the high-quality assets, which we think we can acquire at attractive prices at good discounts replacement costs, double-digit IRRs and again, which we will think will provide better long-term total returns in the assets that we're selling.So meanwhile, the markets remained open for the assets that we've targeted for disposition. These are assets in non-core markets, where assets in less attractive submarkets with a risk to valuations going forward. So we continue to sell assets through the fourth quarter, sold three deals in North Carolina, a 37-year-old deal in Atlanta, a 48-year-old asset in Rockville, Maryland. We've also got a pretty good pipeline of potential dispositions in 2010. We're currently working on several more deals in North Carolina, which will nearly complete our exit from that market, working on a portfolio of smaller assets in our non-Boston, new England markets and a property in Jacksonville, Florida just to name a few.But I want to just as everybody understand that our motivation to sell today has changed as of late. Going forward, we will continue to sell if we can find attractive acquisition opportunities that it make sense to recycle that capital into. Because in 2010, we don't expect to be selling to raise capital for liquidity and debt repayment purposes that was behind much of the selling over the last couple of years. Our thinking is now back to what it was prior to the credit meltdown that will be a seller if we think we have a core market reinvestment opportunity that will provide a better, long-term total return on our capital.On the development front, our focus in 2009 was to complete the lease and to stabilize our existing deals. And we're very pleased with our progress on all fronts. During the year, we completed six assets, totaling $670 million of development cost. We've stabilized seven projects, totaling nearly 1,600 units. In the fourth quarter alone, we leased 375 units and had 338 new move-ins just in the fourth quarter of 2009.Now like everywhere, our rents are below our expectations, they are down about 18% on average on a net effective basis from our original underwriting but that's just the fact of what's going on out there in the marketplace today. We have four projects that remain under construction at the end of 2009. This range from 70% to 98 or so percent complete but with only $140 million yet to fund to complete construction on those assets.But as noted in the last night's release, we have added a property to our development pipeline. We have acquired a leasehold interest in a land partial in New York City. This is at the southwest corner of 10th Avenue and 23rd Street in Chelsea right next to the Highline, which is an incredible, incredible thing for that neighborhood, just a great amenity.This was a distressed situation, in which we acquired this interest from an investor who had completed the foundations out-of-pocket but was unable to get financing to go vertical. So the project that had little activity for nearly a year and a half. And we acquired this interest for about 50% of what the seller had into all of the site and foundation work, as well as the architectural and the engineering design work.And we simultaneously entered into an amended ground lease, which didn't really change the economics any, but it did make the lease more commercially reasonable to us and it was necessarily for us go forward the transaction. So on this site, we'll build 111 apartment units beginning as early as the second quarter of 2010 that will include 9,400 square feet of prime retail at just a tremendous corner in the Chelsea neighborhood.Total cost, about $53 million, 100% of these units will be market rate. We've underwritten a 7%, a mid-7% yield on cost and that's at current rents today. And the deal is subject to a 421-A, 10-year tax abatement which is a favorable tax treatment for that site. This really was a unique situation. I got to tell you that our development team led Megumi Brod really brought to the table, and we just did a phenomenal job of making that happen for us and we're really excited about it. So with that, I will turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us on today's call. This morning, I will focus primarily on our fourth quarter performance and our guidance for the first quarter and full year 2010. Same-store NOI declined 6.3% in the quart
componenttext: Thanks, David. Good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us on today's call. This morning, I will focus primarily on our fourth quarter performance and our guidance for the first quarter and full year 2010. Same-store NOI declined 6.3% in the quarter, compared to the fourth quarter of last year. Revenue was consistent with our expectations and expenses were better than our expectations.For the quarter, our same-store total revenues decreased 4.7% over the fourth quarter of 2008 due to a 4.5% decrease in average rental rate and a 20 basis point decline in occupancy to 94%. Same-store expenses were down 1.9% on a quarter-over-quarter basis, driven primarily by decreases in real estate taxes and payroll. Our expense categories are broken out in our detailed disclosure on Page 14 of the press release.As most of you know, real estate taxes and payroll are two of our three biggest expense categories. Together, they constitute approximately half of our combined same-store operating expenses. Real estate taxes were down because lower valuations were realized more quickly than we expected and because of our success with appeals.Payroll is down because of the adjustments to accruals, lower headcount and less overtime. The third biggest expense category is utilities, which is about 15% of our expenses. And those expenses were up only 2.7% quarter-over-quarter, less than we expected due primarily to lower energy costs. The next big category, repairs and maintenance costs were down mainly because turnover was down 1.3% for the quarter. And I know that turnover was down 2.7% for the full year.Regarding FFO, we had a terrific incremental contribution about $6.3 million in the quarter from our lease sub-properties. For the full year lease subs contributed an incremental $23.2 million to our FFO results in 2009. Our FFO was $0.52 per share for the quarter, down from $0.61 per share for the fourth quarter of 2008 after adjusting for a one-time items, including the 2008 land impairment charge, and debt extinguishment gain and the 2009 tender offer charge. This difference was primarily due to a decrease in same-store NOI at about $0.06 per share, and $0.06 per share of dilution from our 2008 and our 2009 net disposition activity, offset by the $0.02 per share of higher lease-up results that I just referred to. 2009 was challenging and we came through it well. So with 2009 behind us, let's take a look at 2010.On Page 25 of the release, you will find the assumptions underlying our annual FFO guidance. We have also listed in the release the primary drivers of the difference between 2009 and 2010. Let me discuss further a few key items.On the revenue side, Fred gave some wonderful color on our numbers and I wanted to add a few points to help put our 2010 guidance in perspective, compared to our 2009 results. During 2009, our same-store quarter-over-quarter revenue numbers became progressively worse as the impact of the roll down and net effective new lease rates went through our rent roll.In 2010, we expect our same-store quarter-over-quarter revenue numbers to grow progressively better with the possibility that same-store revenues for the fourth quarter of 2010, when compared to the first quarter of 2009 maybe minimally positive. This is mostly due to the easier comparable periods we will face in later 2010, as well as the improved occupancy in 2010 that Fred discussed.On the expense side, we set a same-store guidance range of up 1% to up 2%. We expect utility increases of approximately 3% and real estate tax increases of approximately 2%. We believe we can manage payroll expenses effectively and continue to find ways to control other costs while keeping our properties in excellent shape. And I know that same-store expenses were essentially flat in 2009 for the year, down 0.1%, after having growth of only 2.2% in 2008 and 2.1% in 2007, which again makes for a very tough comparison period for 2010, but Fred and David Santee are up to attack.The primary drivers of the difference between the midpoint of our first quarter 2010 FFO guidance of $0.50 per share, and our 2009 fourth quarter actual FFO and I'm excluding the tender offer charge of $0.52 per share are as follows: A negative impact of $0.03 per share from the lower same-store NOI. As I explained earlier, our first quarter 2010 same-store revenue will be down more than the negative 2% annual guidance midpoint, but it will be better than the negative 4.7% quarter-over-quarter number we reported for the fourth quarter of 2009. And I expect a positive impact of approximately $0.01 per share from lower interest expense.Our full year 2010 FFO guidance were $1.95 to $2.15 per share as four main moving pieces when compared to 2009. Lower same-store NOI, dilution from transaction activity, accretion from lease-ups and lower interest expense.On the NOI side, we expect lower same-store NOI of about $0.16 per share. As for transaction dilution, we anticipate transaction dilution of about $0.11 per share, that consists of $0.10 of dilution of our net sales activity in 2009 and a $0.01 of dilution from our 2010 transaction activity.As for lease-ups, we anticipate a positive impact of about $0.09 per share from lease-up activity. And finally, on interest expense, I expect a positive impact of about $0.03 per share from lower interest expense and this comes from the lower debt balances, costs from paying of debt both at maturity and through tenders. But this is somewhat offset by a reduction in capitalized interest due to our much smaller active development pipeline in 2010.Now on the capital expenditures. As described in Footnote 9 on Page 22, in 2010 we expect to spend about $825 per unit without major rehabs and about $1,075 per unit with rehabs. In 2010, we estimate that same-store routine replacements will run about $350 per same-store unit. We expect to spend approximately $29.3 million on major unit rehabs on about 3,900 units, which is about $7,500 per unit. This will equate to approximately $250 per unit on averaged out over the entire same-store sales portfolio. We estimate that we will spend approximately $475 per unit on building improvements in 2010.I also want to highlight the impact on 2010 earnings and FFO of some relatively new accounting guidance that will impact us more in 2010 than it did in 2009. This will requires us to expense survey, title outside legal expenses and other similar costs we incur in acquiring existing operating properties. Prior to 2009, these costs on successful acquisitions would have been capitalized.Our past history is that on average, we spend about 50 basis points or half a percent of a property's purchased price on acquisition costs. Therefore, based on our acquisitions guidance of $1 billion, we have budgeted about $5 million of such costs in 2010 with about $2.5 million or $0.01 per share of these costs being incurred in the first quarter.These expenses run through the other expenses line item on the income statement. We have added the other expenses line to our guidance assumptions on Page 25.A quick note on the funding sources for this year's transaction activity. We began 2010 with approximately $150 million of cash available for investment and approximately $250 million in disposition proceeds in our 1031 escrow account. We have budgeted funding this year's acquisition activity with a combination of this $400 million along with expected proceeds from future property dispositions. We will pay off approximately $250 million of debt this year, all of it is secured debt. After adjustments for net operating cash flow and some minimal development spending, we expect to have a balance on our unsecured line of credit of about $225 million at the end of 2010.Given that our line cost is about 50 basis points above LIBOR or 75 basis point in total right now, a bit of line usage does not bother us at all. In the second half of 2009, the capital markets continued to improve substantially, causing us to be more confident in our ability to refinance our future debt maturities. As a result, the company conducted a debt tender offer in order to put to use cash the company had stockpiled in early 2009 to address 2010 through 2011 debt maturities.As you can see on Page 17, we spent about $366 million, retiring about $344 million in 2011 and 2012 unsecured debt. Consistent with our strategy, these past two years, we view the tender as a prudent cash management step and as a means to whittle away at our 2011 and 2012 debt maturities. We will remain vigilant of our liquidity position and debt maturity schedule. And now, I'll turn the call back over to David.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Before we open the call to questions, I'd like to reemphasize a couple of points that we discussed already. The first is, it relates to operations. Now we will experience a second year of negative same-store revenue growth in 2010. But as
componenttext: Thank you, Mark. Before we open the call to questions, I'd like to reemphasize a couple of points that we discussed already. The first is, it relates to operations. Now we will experience a second year of negative same-store revenue growth in 2010. But as Fred said, we expect fundamentals to improve ever so slightly as the year progresses, because net effect, the new lease rates are turning a bit positive, renewal rates have turned upward just a little bit and we expect an incremental increase in average occupancy for the year. But we are a long way from a recovery. There is -- these are certainly positive signs for the apartment business. And lastly on the investment side, the Macklowe purchase, as well as the land lease deal for the result of our ability to move quickly, our ability to deal with complex structures and issues, and our ability to fund with cash on hand regardless of deal size. These attributes enable us to get direct looks at these terrific opportunities and we are very hopeful we'll see more of them, as the year progresses. So with that, Chris, we'll be happy to open the call to Q&A.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of David Toti with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of David Toti with Citigroup.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael Bilerman is here with me as well. My first question has to do with the acquisition. I know  you provided some detail on this, but can you walk us through some of your underwriting, sort of, outlines relative to what kind of growth you're expecting
componenttext: Michael Bilerman is here with me as well. My first question has to do with the acquisition. I know  you provided some detail on this, but can you walk us through some of your underwriting, sort of, outlines relative to what kind of growth you're expecting? The cap rates are pretty low on a relative basis, so I'm just wondering what you're thinking about in terms of growth exit cap rates, where the risk is, especially with respect to the New York City acquisitions?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, cap rates are low on a relative basis. If cap rates are high, depending on how far back one wants to go. Now I'll tell you, particularly, the rates at New York City, we went back over almost 12 years of history to look at where cap rates have been.
componenttext: Well, cap rates are low on a relative basis. If cap rates are high, depending on how far back one wants to go. Now I'll tell you, particularly, the rates at New York City, we went back over almost 12 years of history to look at where cap rates have been. And these are the highest cap rates that we've seen over that time period. And obviously, we look at cap rate, we're also looking at what our price per pound is. And we're very, very pleased with being able to acquire these assets at $470 a door and $545 or so a square foot. But we think replacement cost net market gave us probably $800, or if not $900 per square foot or perhaps more. I will tell you, in 2010 in the acquisitions, we've written revenues down 3% during the year. And then we are forecasting improvements in rents going forward. And on the residuals, I could tell you that our residual prices per square foot are in the range of what we think replacement cost is on those assets today. So we're very comfortable with that. Clearly, there are risks on all these, but I will tell you that the ability to buy assets today at the discounts replacement console we have, particularly this macro portfolio, I would be very surprised if we did not wildly exceed what we think our currently low double-digit IRRs on an unleveraged basis.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just along those lines, relative to replacement costs. How do you underwrite the risk to replacement costs benchmarks given the squishiness of land prices in today's environment?
componenttext: And then just along those lines, relative to replacement costs. How do you underwrite the risk to replacement costs benchmarks given the squishiness of land prices in today's environment?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I will say particularly in the instance of the deals we've acquired in Macklowe, forget about the marks. I mean there is just no land. The ability -- it's nearly impossible to assemble the types of land parts or the footprints needed to build these d
componenttext: Well I will say particularly in the instance of the deals we've acquired in Macklowe, forget about the marks. I mean there is just no land. The ability -- it's nearly impossible to assemble the types of land parts or the footprints needed to build these deals today. So I guess I will just tell you that we looked elsewhere around Manhattan, and try and make some judgment as to whether or not it's somewhere between $200 or as much as $300 per net rentable foot. We've got a great team in New York that are working on our deals. They're working on the Chelsea deals, trying to make sure these things triangulate and there's symmetry about it all. But you're absolutely right, it's extremely difficult and challenging to try and determine what the replacement cost would be, particularly on the land value of something that you couldn't replace. Well, even more so, do we feel great about our price per pound on these acquisitions.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: My last question just has to do with more of a portfolio strategy. I think you've sent some pretty bullish signals relative to modest signs of improvement. And at the same time, occupancies sort of continue to ratchet up. At what point do you tack in a di
componenttext: My last question just has to do with more of a portfolio strategy. I think you've sent some pretty bullish signals relative to modest signs of improvement. And at the same time, occupancies sort of continue to ratchet up. At what point do you tack in a different direction and let occupancy begin to drop as you hold prices a little bit firmer? Or do you think that doesn't happen simultaneously?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: This is David Santee. I would say that our occupancies, probably if you looked across the public space, our occupancies have been, I would say, on the low side relative to our competitors. We don't chase occupancy. Our strategy is more about optimizing th
componenttext: This is David Santee. I would say that our occupancies, probably if you looked across the public space, our occupancies have been, I would say, on the low side relative to our competitors. We don't chase occupancy. Our strategy is more about optimizing the two inputs, which is rate and occupancy. So we made the decision early in the year to try not to get involved in the moving concession games, stick with our net effective rent strategy. And frankly, put a lot of faith and effort into using LRO as it was intended to be used.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Levy with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Levy with Macquarie.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you please talk as a follow-up to David's question about the competitiveness against, which your purchasing assets? Are you bidding against the same number of buyers that we're looking at purchasing the Pentagon Row asset?
componenttext: Can you please talk as a follow-up to David's question about the competitiveness against, which your purchasing assets? Are you bidding against the same number of buyers that we're looking at purchasing the Pentagon Row asset?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Pentagon Row asset, which we acquired in the fourth quarter, there was a very significant competitive bidding process. In all of the other deals that we've acquired, Michael, there is either been an absolute direct transaction or a process by which
componenttext: On the Pentagon Row asset, which we acquired in the fourth quarter, there was a very significant competitive bidding process. In all of the other deals that we've acquired, Michael, there is either been an absolute direct transaction or a process by which there was a very small group of people that had been approached. You are right that there is a lot of money out there, coming back from the National Multi Housing Council meeting in Florida last month, I can tell you that there is a lot of money out there and a lot of people that would like to buy more of multifamily assets for all the reasons that we talked about. Extremely competitive and smaller price point transaction, a very competitive and stabilized assets. And we're fortunate that we bought some things that come to us direct. We bought some things that -- we had some conversations with some people months ago who might have come back to us and said, maybe, "I'm willing to talk to you today.", and  we were able to do something on a direct basis. The Pentagon Row would be the only deal that I would suggest to you, it has been, was one that was fully brokered and heavily shot. My objective this year is to buy as much as we can outside of a large heavily brokered process. I'm not interested in being the winning bidder out of 100 people chasing some of these stuff. I think that the size of the Macklowe transaction, of their desire for something to be done quickly and confidentially, enables us to get that transaction done. And I'm hopeful that we'll be able to shape some other things for us. We've got a lot of very capable, very confident acquisition people around the country that know locals, and we're trying to get conversations, trying to get as much done as we can on a direct basis.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think, this is another follow-up to David's question, that when you gave projections as to where you think revenues may be headed over the first couple of years, post-purchase, do you think, is that based on your market view? Or based more on the f
componenttext: Do you think, this is another follow-up to David's question, that when you gave projections as to where you think revenues may be headed over the first couple of years, post-purchase, do you think, is that based on your market view? Or based more on the fact that you have a stronger platform and you might be able to drive yield higher through a more efficient operations from the get-go?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well,, I would tell you that I think on most properties we underwrite on the expense side, we do believe we can have some immediate savings on expenses. And I'll tell you that as we project, what were we expect rents could go going forward, I think it's m
componenttext: Well,, I would tell you that I think on most properties we underwrite on the expense side, we do believe we can have some immediate savings on expenses. And I'll tell you that as we project, what were we expect rents could go going forward, I think it's more of a view of an individual market, of what we think the supply constraints are in that individual market, what we think both expectations, demographic trends are in that particular market, and that the input that, that will have on revenue. But I'm not suggesting that we're buying stuff because we think we can get a whole lot more revenue than the next guy. Perhaps we can, but we are not paying a third-party for that.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: In the South Florida market, can you talk a little bit about the strength you're seeing? Are there tenants that are moving into the QR assets coming from foreclosed assets? Or they're taking a quality uptick or are the folks have just moved down to the ar
componenttext: In the South Florida market, can you talk a little bit about the strength you're seeing? Are there tenants that are moving into the QR assets coming from foreclosed assets? Or they're taking a quality uptick or are the folks have just moved down to the area? I guess I'm asking that, with the oversupply of housing in the market, it strikes me as a bit that results are as robust as they are there?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Fred Tuomi. We are very pleased with the recent trends at South Florida, which seemed strong. The increase of the occupancy, really, about 200 basis points over the same time last year-end. And rents are starting to move up. I'd say in So
componenttext: Michael, this is Fred Tuomi. We are very pleased with the recent trends at South Florida, which seemed strong. The increase of the occupancy, really, about 200 basis points over the same time last year-end. And rents are starting to move up. I'd say in South Florida, we definitely had a lift off. But one of the concerns there, one of the drivers of the downturn was that oversupply of single-family homes, especially concentrated there in the Miami area. The issue there, in our portfolio, we have primarily a suburban portfolio. We're not in the ground zero of all these housing mess down there. From Broward, from Palm Beach, or in the more suburban areas. So we haven't been directly competing with some of these shadow market inventory there, these condos there. It's a little bit on the fringe, our properties nearby, but it really hasn't been a factor. Anecdotally, I have heard recently that the same people who are losing their single-family homes come to rent with us. We welcome them as long as their income qualified, but I do think it's a massive influx. I think the South Florida has been bouncing on the bottom for a couple of years now, and that we're seeing some good signs of demand. They've got some construction, some infrastructure projects going on there. One thing I do worry about South Florida is the continued negative growth in population of households. If that continues, that could be a, kind of a slowdown for us, but so far so good

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dave Bragg with ISI Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dave Bragg with ISI Group.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: David and Fred, your discussion earlier on revenue growth, your outlook there, was helpful. But could you take a top-down approach and help us think about what employment assumption underpins that forecast?
componenttext: David and Fred, your discussion earlier on revenue growth, your outlook there, was helpful. But could you take a top-down approach and help us think about what employment assumption underpins that forecast?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The job forecast is not a primary input to our budgeting, our forecasting model. It's a macro, kind of a secondary, this overall feeling for it. When we look at our business, we do know which markets maybe have gotten hit hard with job losses, which marke
componenttext: The job forecast is not a primary input to our budgeting, our forecasting model. It's a macro, kind of a secondary, this overall feeling for it. When we look at our business, we do know which markets maybe have gotten hit hard with job losses, which markets are continuing, which markets are forecasted to be improving or reaching some sort of stability next year. And we use the same economy.com statistics that others do. We kind of leave it there, it just sets the table. We really run our business based, really, from the bottom up. What are the trends or the metrics that we have available to us? The platform we have now gives us this incredible time series of metrics, incredible visibility. And then on top of that, incredible ability to forecast. And we've been very accurate and very fortunate, thus so far. So we're not so anxious about job number x, or y or z, but more anxious about what's the absorption rate, what's our leasing velocity, what's the traffic, what's the demand patterns, where were we last year, what are the seasonal factors, and what's the occupancy trends and what's the lease trend, what's our sales people are telling us, what's our customers are telling us. I think that's a more effective way to predict a business. We can control versus assuming you're going to have an outcome based on job forecast, which are done by economists, you know what that means, and then setting a strategy that way. We'd rather set a strategy based on what we can control.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Fred, I understand, but ultimately jobs will drive that demand and the absorption that you're looking for. And I'd point out that a couple of your peers did provide this assumption, so therefore it will be helpful for us -- maybe I'll just try it a differ
componenttext: Fred, I understand, but ultimately jobs will drive that demand and the absorption that you're looking for. And I'd point out that a couple of your peers did provide this assumption, so therefore it will be helpful for us -- maybe I'll just try it a different way. A couple of peers suggested that their forecast is based on negative job growth in 2010. If that were to play out, how would that affect your forecast? Would it still hold?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we're not looking at national job forecast. We're in an individual market and we look at the major employers in that particular market. Looking at employers of our residents and trying to make some judgments about what's going on in that market or
componenttext: Again, we're not looking at national job forecast. We're in an individual market and we look at the major employers in that particular market. Looking at employers of our residents and trying to make some judgments about what's going on in that market or sub market. The fact that they lose a bunch of jobs in Cleveland or whatever, doesn't impact us. We're looking at the 15 or so kind of core markets in which we're operating, and try to understand what we think is happening to job activity in those markets. As well as supply and all of the other demand characteristics. But this is not -- we don't start by saying we make this assumption about national job loss or job gain, David. It just doesn't work that way for us.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just drilling down to the 15 or so markets that you mentioned, which of those markets are you seeing the most hiring activity or you're feeling most optimistic about hiring activity? At least in the first half of this year, for example?
componenttext: Just drilling down to the 15 or so markets that you mentioned, which of those markets are you seeing the most hiring activity or you're feeling most optimistic about hiring activity? At least in the first half of this year, for example?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Boston has been very stable, we had some significant job losses last year, but Boston is stabilized and recovering. We've got some good education, government, health care and some technologies issues there that are helping us. Virginia and Maryland, and b
componenttext: Boston has been very stable, we had some significant job losses last year, but Boston is stabilized and recovering. We've got some good education, government, health care and some technologies issues there that are helping us. Virginia and Maryland, and basically the DC Metro, very good job situation. Last couple of years, it's minimally negative. And now, it's going to come back more robust, positive basis. And these are great demographics. The jobs being created in DC right now just fit us perfectly. The young digeratis, they're the employers, they're the first-time accounts, consultants, defense piece, government piece, it all seems to be growing. So DC area is very, very favorable. Denver is coming back. Inland Empire, probably not. Los Angeles is going to be a little sketchy. New York is one that we are seeing some job stabilization and recovery. Anecdotally, our people in New York are telling me just recently that all the big houses are hiring. JPMorgan, Chase, Goldman Sachs. We've got a number of new leases just recently both in Manhattan and over in Jersey, and our lease's up at 70 Greene coming from the bankers. So we're happy to see that sector coming back. So a lot of market -- we're seeing the manufacturing kind of went away. The real estate-related got hammered. The construction, it went away, probably it will be a slow time coming back. But what is coming back right now is some of these, the technology companies, investments in infrastructure, investments in energy. And then also the consultants, the bankers, the engineers and those types of things are starting to come back. Orange County, we're not seeing that. Orlando, it's kind of a mixed bag. Phoenix, not. So it's really kind of a market-by-market situation, the way we look at it. And a one market of note is Seattle. Seattle had significant job losses the last two years, as everyone knows, but it's one of the stronger forecasted recovery markets on the job front. Microsoft just started hiring again. Amazon has been hiring. The WaMu [Washington Mutual] building, which should have recreated the downtown, is going to be replaced with Russell [Russell Investments Center]. So a lot of good things really happening in Seattle. And of course, Boeing [The Boeing Company] right now, has deep backlog of deliveries and they need a lot of people.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we're getting very close to having exited the all target markets that we talked about. And I think we'll complete that process. As well as we'll continue to look at older assets in, perhaps, in some of our core markets or sub-markets that we're less i
componenttext: No, we're getting very close to having exited the all target markets that we talked about. And I think we'll complete that process. As well as we'll continue to look at older assets in, perhaps, in some of our core markets or sub-markets that we're less interested in, or asset that have got some capital issues or valuation risks. And again, as I mentioned earlier, our disposition process will really be a function of our investment opportunities going forward. They will be much more closely linked today than they have been in the past couple of years.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to go to the tender. I just want to get your thoughts, some of your peers did the concurrent issuance with the tender. Speaking to some institutional investors, it sounds like they're pretty receptive to that. I just want to, given your size i
componenttext: I just want to go to the tender. I just want to get your thoughts, some of your peers did the concurrent issuance with the tender. Speaking to some institutional investors, it sounds like they're pretty receptive to that. I just want to, given your size in the unsecured market, just want to get your thoughts on why, on doing that strategy versus just doing the outright tender without the concurrent offering?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: When we thought about the tender, we really thought about it as a primary means to manage our cash. Back in June of '09, when we did the large Freddie Mac secured financing, we were doing that, Alex, with the thought that we would need that money potentia
componenttext: When we thought about the tender, we really thought about it as a primary means to manage our cash. Back in June of '09, when we did the large Freddie Mac secured financing, we were doing that, Alex, with the thought that we would need that money potentially to meet maturities coming up in '09 and in '10. And that we couldn't count on the capital markets to refinance us in the ordinary course. As we all got more confident here about that, we decided late in 2009 to go ahead and apply that cash right now to maturities, the nearest public maturities we had which were the '11s and '12s that we took out. The reason we didn't couple that with another issuances is we frankly didn't need the cash. I mean the only reason to do an issuance in connection with the tender, I think, is to either extend duration or to manage interest rate risk. And we've done some hedging away from this, that we think manage interest rate risk is just fine. Our duration stands at seven years, we think that's okay. So we just felt that we had managed that risk in another way and that, that was just as effective or more effective, frankly.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on that duration, what's the split between secured versus unsecured duration?
componenttext: And just on that duration, what's the split between secured versus unsecured duration?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Secured versus unsecured duration. It's a, nine years is our secured duration. And unsecured is five.
componenttext: Secured versus unsecured duration. It's a, nine years is our secured duration. And unsecured is five.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question is, given that the trillion in the quarter buyback program is almost, I guess, coming to an end in March. What are you guys hearing or what's the take on GSE rate? Is there a view that they will go up and that will make other
componenttext: And then the second question is, given that the trillion in the quarter buyback program is almost, I guess, coming to an end in March. What are you guys hearing or what's the take on GSE rate? Is there a view that they will go up and that will make other portfolio lenders more competitive, or are the GSEs going to try to compress spread and hold rate?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The GSEs have done a pretty good job of, frankly, lowering their guarantee fees, their profit, to try and keep their rates in that 5.5% to 6% quarter, Alex, to date. I can't accurately predict the future very well in that, but I would say is as those rate
componenttext: The GSEs have done a pretty good job of, frankly, lowering their guarantee fees, their profit, to try and keep their rates in that 5.5% to 6% quarter, Alex, to date. I can't accurately predict the future very well in that, but I would say is as those rates go up, investors, I think, would start to buy that security. So it comes a bit of a comparative, comparatively more attractive security. So again, as the Fed withdraws support and maybe government agencies otherwise stop purchasing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, MBS and conduit product, I think other investors, fixed income investors will step up. Because there's just such a hunger for yield in this climate that, that will offset it. So could it go up modestly? Absolutely. But I don't see a big jerk up here, just because again I think there is so much fixed income demand that any yieldy product like this, will get it up.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just given the appetite for yield, what is -- I mean you guys are big unsecured issuer, what would it take for you guys to come to market? What are you looking for in the market to issue?
componenttext: Just given the appetite for yield, what is -- I mean you guys are big unsecured issuer, what would it take for you guys to come to market? What are you looking for in the market to issue?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, when we need the money and we have a debt maturity that's coming up, we'll do that. At the end of the year, we're only going to be $250 million on the line. I mean a pretty modest line exposure, $225 million on the line. So I do expect that in the
componenttext: Again, when we need the money and we have a debt maturity that's coming up, we'll do that. At the end of the year, we're only going to be $250 million on the line. I mean a pretty modest line exposure, $225 million on the line. So I do expect that in the next year or so, we'll access the debt markets in one way or another. And I think we'd prefer that be the unsecured market but, until we need the money, just stockpiling it and curing that dilution around. That's been the plan the last two years, and i just don't see the need for it at this point anymore. So when we need the money, we'll borrow the money.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Michelle Ko with Bank of America.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just along the same lines, you know, recently one of your peers had issue on unsecured debt. If you were to tap the market today, what rates do you think you'd be able to obtain?
componenttext: Just along the same lines, you know, recently one of your peers had issue on unsecured debt. If you were to tap the market today, what rates do you think you'd be able to obtain?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we could do a ten-year unsecured at maybe 175 or so over the 10 years. I think that's in the 5.5%, 5.75% range, really. The really interesting thing to show related on that is that there's getting to be a great compression between Fannie, Freddie
componenttext: I think we could do a ten-year unsecured at maybe 175 or so over the 10 years. I think that's in the 5.5%, 5.75% range, really. The really interesting thing to show related on that is that there's getting to be a great compression between Fannie, Freddie rates, at least for us. Our Fannie, Freddie rate and our unsecured borrowing rate. So if those two are pretty close together -- you might remember that gap has been pretty large and that's why we are pretty big secured borrower. As that gap tightens, that makes us much more inclined to borrow unsecured in the future, than secured.

componenttext: Actually I'm just wondering if you could talk about what markets you might like to increase your exposure in?

componenttext: I'll tell you, Michelle, we don't have a particular goals in any of the individual markets, but we have been focused over the past five or so years on the New York, Washington, Boston, Southern Cal, Seattle San Francisco. So you would to see us acquiring, well if you'd likely be in those markets. We consider those to be our core markets, and say our activity will be in those markets.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a color, you did talk about rates on renewals, and obviously you guys are seeing some modest increases here. What are you sensing from your competitors at this point? Are they buying occupancy or they're changing the game as well, and starting to bum
componenttext: Just a color, you did talk about rates on renewals, and obviously you guys are seeing some modest increases here. What are you sensing from your competitors at this point? Are they buying occupancy or they're changing the game as well, and starting to bump up rates?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing we see on the competitive side of, that's really important is, the new lease of competition. In certain pockets of areas where we have supply still working through the system, that will disrupt a local market or sub-market basis. So if some
componenttext: The only thing we see on the competitive side of, that's really important is, the new lease of competition. In certain pockets of areas where we have supply still working through the system, that will disrupt a local market or sub-market basis. So if someone starts offering one month, two month, in some cases, you hear a three months free rent, on a lease up, until they get stabilized, that will kind of disrupt the market. And sometimes that does impact not only your net effective new lease rates, but also you're renewal rates. if you get more -- more customers may come to you and say, "Well gee, I could go off get a brand new property for two months off." That's really the most kind of noticeable change. Other than that, I really don't see any kind of disruptive behavior, competitive threat, from anyone else, to our core markets, our core assets.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the move out to single-family? I think you expect turnover to be roughly flat year-over-year?
componenttext: Can you talk about the move out to single-family? I think you expect turnover to be roughly flat year-over-year?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: This is David Santee. When you look back over the past fourth quarter, there was a lot of news about increased home buying. When I look at our market, at first glance, on a percentage basis, the percentage of move out, those numbers were quite elevated. B
componenttext: This is David Santee. When you look back over the past fourth quarter, there was a lot of news about increased home buying. When I look at our market, at first glance, on a percentage basis, the percentage of move out, those numbers were quite elevated. But if you look at our actual turnover, which was considerably lower, you convert those to a raw numbers, the numbers just, they're not meaningful. Probably the most two meaningful markets, as far as increased move outs to buy homes, are Phoenix and Northern Virginia. And those, in Q4, those numbers were elevated well above Q4, even 2008. But when you look back at over 2008, 2009, 2007, across almost all of these markets, very few markets are even close to 2007 levels.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess as you think about in terms of acquisitions you still got another $500 million to go for the balance of this year. In which markets are you seeing the greatest discount to replace the cost, is it New York or is that really a unique situation?
componenttext: And I guess as you think about in terms of acquisitions you still got another $500 million to go for the balance of this year. In which markets are you seeing the greatest discount to replace the cost, is it New York or is that really a unique situation?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think New York was indeed a unique situation. It all depends and who knows where pricing goes from here Jay. Just this past acquisitions are no indications of what future acquisitions are going to be. So I don't really know. But we have been -- we
componenttext: Well I think New York was indeed a unique situation. It all depends and who knows where pricing goes from here Jay. Just this past acquisitions are no indications of what future acquisitions are going to be. So I don't really know. But we have been -- we did think New York was a pretty sizable discount replacement cost, and it would certainly more of a discount than the other deals we've been buying, which you probably been more 90% of replacement cost down to more like 80% of replacement cost. But this remains to be seen based upon the opportunities that are presented.

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: But what about the distressed selling of land deal, are you seeing see more of that activity as well?
componenttext: But what about the distressed selling of land deal, are you seeing see more of that activity as well?

headline: Equity Residential, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Not really, not distressed enough for pricing to make sense, at least in our judgment. I'm not suggesting that land parcels are not today available at lower prices than they were in the not-too-distant past but they still are not making sense to us, relat
componenttext: Not really, not distressed enough for pricing to make sense, at least in our judgment. I'm not suggesting that land parcels are not today available at lower prices than they were in the not-too-distant past but they still are not making sense to us, relative to what our acquisition opportunities are. So as long as we believe we can buy existing streams of income at the right price, we would probably would favor that. I will tell you, we are looking at acquisitions and we're constantly underwriting things but have not yet seen anything from a new purchase standpoint outside of the unique situation in manhattan that would -- is getting us moving towards taking down new land parcels today.
