componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Paula, and Ill be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Equity Residential third quarter earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. Thank you.
Mr. McKenna, you may begin your conference.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paula. Good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss Equity Residentials third quarter 2010 results. Our featured speakers today are David Neithercut, our President and CEO and Mark Parrell, our Chief Financial Officer. Fred Tuomi, our
componenttext:
Thanks, Paula. Good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss Equity Residentials third quarter 2010 results. Our featured speakers today are David Neithercut, our President and CEO and Mark Parrell, our Chief Financial Officer. Fred Tuomi, our EVP of Property Management and David Santee, our EVP of Property Operations, are also here with us for the Q&A.
Certain matters discussed during the conference call may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities law. These forward-looking statements are subject to certain economic risks and uncertainties. The company assumes no obligation to update or supplement these statements that become untrue because of subsequent events.
Now Ill turn it over to David.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marty, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. We are extremely pleased with the operating performance of the company thus far, and wed like to acknowledge the hard work that the entire team is doing out there to deliver tha
componenttext:
Thank you, Marty, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. We are extremely pleased with the operating performance of the company thus far, and wed like to acknowledge the hard work that the entire team is doing out there to deliver that performance. So, thank you all so [ph] very much for what you do each and every day for us.
We have come an awfully long way in the last year and this is really the result of continued strength in each of the four areas that Fred Tuomi on prior calls has pointed out as key factors for driving performance for us.
The first was retention, which we estimate will improve 4.5 to 5 percentage points over the last year, because our turnover in 2009 was about 61.3%, and we think that will improve to around 56.5% or so in 2010. And I want to add that both of these figures are inclusive of the onsite transfers and those between EQR properties, so that the really net true move out is even better than that.
Our renewal rates in September, we achieved renewal rate increases of 5.1%. In October, those renewal rate increases we achieved were 5.5% and on the 2,500 leases renewed thus far for November, we are achieving a 5.7% increase.
Occupancy which was 93.8% in 2009, will average more than a 100 basis points higher in 2010 and occupancy currently at 94.8% today, is a very strong level for this time of the year.
In our base rents, those being new rents were asking for our new residents to pay, these asking rents are up 8.7% since the beginning of the year on a weighted average basis across the portfolio. As a result of this, weve recovered a significant portion of the discounts in rents that we gave our residence in 2008 and 2009.
We now have only about 5% more rate growth left to reestablish peak pricing across the portfolio and thats helped by some markets that have already surpassed the prior high watermarks and are now creating new peak pricing levels. So, we remain very optimistic as we wrap up the year and we move into 2011.
Now we know theres a bit of disbelief out there about how well the apartment space is doing, despite any kind of real meaningful job growth. Ill be honest with you by saying that, when we look at our dashboards and we see continued improvement in these four years that I just mentioned and then, we look ourselves at the newspaper headlines, we ask ourselves the same thing. We ask ourselves this question without taking our foot off the gas on rental increases I will tell you, but we do ask the same thing.
In addition all of the things that weve talked about over the course of this year that have positively impacted apartment fundamentals such as, the powerful demographic picture comprised of $80 million plus echo-boomers.
The fact is theres been virtually no new supply added to core markets across the country, as well as the changing dynamic with respect to the wisdom and benefits of single-family home ownership.
The Head of our Research Department, the smart guy by the name of Jay Lybik reminds us about the importance of household growth and that well job growth certainly fuels household growth, household growth can and does occur without job growth and in fact, markets can simultaneously experience household formation, while actually losing jobs.
According to several sources, its estimated that nationally we formed somewhere between 800,000 and 900,000 new households this year and thats the level thats pretty consistent with a year ago, and this compares to a recent period of economic expansion when we were forming about 1.2 million households annually. So, the number is down this year, but its still very meaningful.
Furthermore, notwithstanding what the apartment capture rate might have been of these new households in the past, the likelihood of the new households being created today opting for rental housing rather than home ownership is extremely, extremely high.
So, when one thinks about this increase in household formations at a time of significantly reduced new apartment supply in a time of declining single-family home ownership levels, this can explain a lot of the strength and fundamentals were experiencing today in a period of little new job growth.
In any event, Ill tell you we remained very optimistic about our business prospects and it will only get better as the economy recovers and adds more jobs.
So, on the transaction side, let me tell you that as we noted in the release last night, we acquired six assets in the third quarter for a total of nearly $550 million. That brings the total for the year to 14 assets and $1.4 billion of acquisitions.
The assets we acquired in the third quarter, four of those were in California, two in the San Francisco Bay area, one in Berkley and the other in Burlingame near the San Francisco airport and one each in Los Angeles and San Diego.
We acquired two deals in the D.C. area, one in Arlington, Virginia and the other in Alexandria, Virginia.
Of the five assets that were fully leased, cap rates on these deals ranged from the high 4s at one of the Bay area deal that near airport which is a value-add deal, which should stabilize in the mid 6s to the low 6s on the Alexandria, Virginia acquisition that was adjacent to an existing property that we already own.
The San Diego deal, which we had announced previously is our Vantage Pointe property, which was built in 2009 and contains 679 units. Now that property was 20% leased at acquisition and is obviously subject to a major lease up effort on our part.
Very much like what is happening at our 425 Mass Avenue deal in D.C., which is in lease up we are up and running with Vantage Pointe and thats from a standing start.
Likewise, like the Mass Avenue deal from a standing start, were just doing phenomenal job there and thus far the team has leased 61 units in the first month of ownership and we are extremely excited about that and net effect in pro forma rents that were modestly above what we had projected. Were very confident that deal was stabilized at a 7% plus yield on current rents today.
Now based up on what weve acquired thus far this year and that which we are looking at today, weve increased our acquisition guidance for the year to $1.5 billion. We continue to work on a handful of deals that couldnt close yet this year in Boston, in D.C., in LA and San Francisco.
Ill tell you we have seen an increase in the number of deals being offered for sale on our core markets, but there remains considerable competition for most of these assets.
Cap rates obviously compressed significantly throughout the year, but we now think that they have stabilized in the low 4s to mid 5s at least in our core markets. As a result values, which were growing dramatically for much of the year, they continue our growth today, but we think at a slower rate and our rate of growth, which we think is more in line with NOI growth.
Ill tell you we continue to try and find ways to achieve better overall returns by looking at deals with the lease up risk like Vantage Pointe and the 425 Mass deal, deals with value add or repositioning opportunities. But simply put, deals of all sorts other than fully stabilized core assets, will attract the interest of a lot for this institutional capital.
On the disposition side, we sold three wholly-owned assets during the quarter as well as our 25% interest in 24 properties held in joint venture with an institutional partner that we formed 10 years ago.
Two of the three wholly-owned assets we sold were in Stockton, California and the other one in Dallas, Texas, which is we continue our exit from our non-core markets.
Now you will recall that we have significantly slowed our disposition pace earlier in the year because we thought that more fundamentals end values would recover as the year progressed. As a result, we intentionally sold only a $172 million in the first nine months of the year.
We did ramp up our offerings for sale mid-year because values did in fact recover as the strong bid for sticks and bricks made its way into lesser quality assets and into non-core markets.
We know have about $300 million under contract, we have another $300 million under letter of intent and even more in various stages of marketing. So, we have readjusted our 2010 disposition guidance to $750 million for the calendar year.
Even at this reduced level, its obvious weve got a lot of work to do to make that number by the end of the year and its certainly possible that we will. But if we miss, it will only be because some of the closings has slipped into January of next year, because we are committed to selling our non-strategic assets, and we think that at current pricing based on a lot of which is on Fannie and Freddie interest rates liquidity, we think its a good time to be selling those assets we dont think we want to own in the mid-term and we certainly intend to do so.
Im pleased to say on the development side, we continue to make great progress on our development assets. Deals are being completed on time and under budget. Leasing continues to exceed our forecast on absorption and like our stabilized assets, were enjoying a lift in net effective rates.
Thus far this year, weve commenced construction on two projects; one in Manhattans Chelsea neighborhood and the other our third and final phase of a property in Denver, Colorado.
We have also acquired six land partners thus far this year. A site in Arlington, Virginia that wed announced earlier in the year, three sites in the third quarter; one in Berkeley, California, one in Alexandria, Virginia, and one in Miami, Florida; and two sites in the Seattle that closed earlier this week.
Now, we expect to be able to begin construction on most of these sites in 2011 and that would represent nearly 340 million of starts next year on these parcels alone. We expect yields at current rents in the mid 6% to mid 7% range on these starts.
In addition, we have some land sites that were acquired before the downturn that are under consideration for near-term construction starts, and we also remain very active underwriting new development opportunities.
Of course though, when we look at development opportunities, we do sell along with acquisition opportunities during the best risk-adjusted returns we can on our invested capital and we will continue to deploy our capital accordingly. Mark?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Good morning everyone. Thank you for joining us on todays call. This morning, Im going to focus on three areas. First, our third quarter performance, especially our expense performance, our revised guidance for 2010, and then just a l
componenttext:
Thanks, David. Good morning everyone. Thank you for joining us on todays call. This morning, Im going to focus on three areas. First, our third quarter performance, especially our expense performance, our revised guidance for 2010, and then just a little bit of a discussion on our balance sheet and the impact of some of our transactional activity on the balance sheet.
Since David has already provided good color on the drivers for our revenue performance, Im going to move right on to expenses. Same store expenses increased 1.9% on a quarter-over-quarter basis.
Were very pleased to deliver this strong performance on expenses. This is especially true, because in our comparable period last year expenses decreased 0.6%.
In fact, assuming, we deliver our guidance number of 1.5% increase in operating expenses for 2010, over the last four years, our operating expenses would have grown at an average annual rate of just 1.4%.
We have delivered consistent restrained expense growth, while maintaining terrific customer loyalty, due to efforts of our colleagues at our properties throughout the country, as well as in the Property Operations team in Chicago. Well done, everyone.
I also want to take a look at three of our big expense drivers. We call them the Big Three here. Real estate taxes, first on the real estate side, we had a 4.3% reduction in property taxes quarter-over-quarter, and this was due to changes in the accrual rates.
Its customary that during the third quarter of each year, we receive rate and evaluation information from most of our properties in the various taxing authorities, we take that information, and we use it to reset our accruals.
The reason were resetting our accruals as weve said on prior calls is that we continue to experience favorable real estate tax results as lower revaluations of our properties by local governments are occurring, without at least to this point increases in tax rates.
We are also having considerable success with our appeals. We now expect real estate taxes to be down about 1.5% for the year, and I remind everyone that real estate taxes are about a quarter of our property operating expenses.
Second big expense driver for us is onsite payroll, it also makes up about a quarter of our operating expenses. It was up 4.7% in the quarter. As was true for real estate taxes, adjustments to accrual rates in this case accrual rates on health insurance, workmens compensation, and bonuses, drove most of the change in this line item during this quarter.
We increased our accruals for both health insurance and workmens comp. I dont think this is a surprise to anyone that health and material cost continue to rise, though the rate of increase was more than we had expected.
Also, based on our improved operating performance we are accruing for a higher level of bonuses this year, after being down considerably in this line item last year. We budgeted for onsite payroll this year to be up to 1.5% and now see it as being up about 2.5%.
Excluding the extraordinary over time costs we incurred in the first quarter of this year, due to the big snow storms in the Northeast, this line item would have been up a bit less than 2% year-to-date.
Our final big expense item is utility costs. These constitute about 15% of our operating expenses and they were up 3.5% in the quarter. One third of our utility expenses or said another way 5% of total operating expenses are directly energy related.
Gas costs were lower than we expected this quarter and we expect that trend to continue as we have locked the cost of the large portion of our 2011 natural gas usage at lower levels in 2010.
Two-thirds of utility expenses or 10% of our property operating expenses are water, sewer and trash and are not directly driven by changes in energy costs. Instead changes in water and sewer rates, cash by municipalities that are tight on cash at the moment have driven up these numbers lately. In the quarter, they were up 6%. At the beginning of the year, we expected utility cost to be up 3%, we now expect about a 2% year-over-year increase in this category.
In summary, were comfortable that our operating expenses will increase about 1.5% this year, because modest growth in utilities and payroll will be offset by decline in property taxes.
Now Im going to talk a little bit about guidance. We expect our same store operating performance to be right in line with the guidance that we provided back in July. For the full year, we expect revenues to be down 0.25%.
We expect same store expenses to be up 1.5% and our resulting same store NOI to be down 1.25%. We expect same store fourth quarter sequential revenues to be roughly flat when compared to the third quarter.
Pure rental revenue which is the combined impact of rental rate and occupancy will be up 0.5% or half a percent or better on a sequential basis. But in the fourth quarter we will sign fewer new leases, due to seasonally slower demand and renew fewer existing leases due to lower exploration volume. Thus we will have fewer opportunities to grow our in place rents.
Also with lower levels of activity, we expect to earn less in transaction-related other income, like application and moving fees, during the lower volume fourth quarter then we earned in the higher volume third quarter. Lower other income will blunt deposit of impact of rates and occupancy at least between the third and fourth quarters.
I do want to mention that we expect same store net operating income to be up $4 million or so between the third and fourth quarters, due to seasonally lower expenses. So for the same reason our revenues go down in the fourth quarter or stay flat our expenses go down. There is less transactional activity, less turnover cost, less maintenance activity.
We also revised our FFO guidance range for the year. Our midpoint is now $2.20 per share, up from the previous midpoint of $2.17 per share. Because our same store operations for the year are going to be right where we thought they would be, a $0.03 midpoint increase us being driven by factors outside of our same store operations, specifically, transaction timing and volume as well as lease ups.
As David described, we purchased a substantial number of operating properties this year. We also just raised our acquisition guidance by $250 million. We also purchased properties earlier in the year than we initially expected. This means more acquisition NOI and FFO in 2010 that we had previously thought.
In addition, we lowered our disposition guidance by $100 million. It is possible that some of our budgeted $750 million in disposition activity will bleed into the beginning of 2011. I would expect cash flow from disposition and acquisition activity to be lumpy and uneven. Transactions do not always neatly close prior to financial statement end dates.
Summing it up, changes in the timing of acquisitions and dispositions will result in a contribution to FFO of about $0.02 per share above our original budget. In addition, our properties and lease up have performed better than expected, contributing $0.01 more than we had budget for the year. Lease ups provide an incremental $9.3 million in the third quarter, and they will provide about $34 million in NOI for us for the entire year.
So, lets turn to the last item and talk a little bit about the impact of our various investment activities on the balance sheet. Some of our leverage statistics were slightly elevated at this quarter end, due to the timing of our disposition and acquisition activities. We think about our credit metrics over multiyear periods, not just at any specific quarter ending. As Ive said before, over time we will fund our investment activity on a leverage-neutral basis.
Getting into the specifics, last quarter, I estimated that by the end of this year we would have about $460 million in cash in our balance sheet and that our $1.4 billion revolving line of credit would be undrawn.
Due to changes in the outlook for transactions activity, I still expect that at the end of the year, our revolving line of credit will be undrawn, but that we will have approximately $135 million in cash.
As I mentioned before the precise timing of our transaction activity is hard to gauge, and we expect to receive substantial additional disposition proceeds in the first part of 2011.
We believe in having a conservative balance sheet that has both great strength and great flexibility between our current total liquidity and our ability to access both the debt and equity markets. We have great confidence in our ability to meet our upcoming obligations and to fund our investment activity.
Operator, were now happy to take questions.

So, Im just wondering whether you think the good time to potentially exit from some of those other markets and do some more asset sales?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its hard to say at this juncture whether or not well be net buyer or seller or neutral. But as I said in my prepared remarks values have recovered to a point and with the liquidity being provided out there by the agencies today, were looking at o
componenttext:
Its hard to say at this juncture whether or not well be net buyer or seller or neutral. But as I said in my prepared remarks values have recovered to a point and with the liquidity being provided out there by the agencies today, were looking at our non-core, non-strategic assets and were probably going to step up the pace of disposition again. We did take our foot off the gas a little bit earlier in the year, because we thought values were at levels that we werent willing to sell at those levels.
Values have certainly improved as the year has gone on. Were seeing more interest in the assets we want to sell and we think well go ahead and hit that bid. I think its the right thing for us to do at this time. How much of it gets done? Were not quite sure, but I dont think it will be totally contingent on what we can find to buy at least at this juncture.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just last question, I know that D.C. and New York are continuing to grow rents nicely right now, but just looking forward to next year, how concerned are you about cuts, defense contractors specifically in Northern Virginia area, as well as potential layo
componenttext: Just last question, I know that D.C. and New York are continuing to grow rents nicely right now, but just looking forward to next year, how concerned are you about cuts, defense contractors specifically in Northern Virginia area, as well as potential layoffs from the banks in New York?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Eric, this is Fred Tuomi. Youre right, D.C. and New York continue to just moderate though the leasing season and poised for a continued strength in terms of demand, rents, renewals all aspects of our fundamental. Those two markets are extremely strong
componenttext:
Eric, this is Fred Tuomi. Youre right, D.C. and New York continue to just moderate though the leasing season and poised for a continued strength in terms of demand, rents, renewals all aspects of our fundamental. Those two markets are extremely strong and favorable and I dont see anything slowing them down.
In the New York specifically, I was just there last week talking to some of our managers and we are seeing on the ground is good, steady, stream of new people coming into New York who formerly were not from New York and they have jobs. Its not just the financial sector, has legal, has professional services, the entertainment business, especially in the upper west side its brining a lots of people into the area.
So, we are not totally dependent on the financial sector. But within the financial sector we arent seeing any further job losses, but the pace of adding has slowed. So, we think that the financial sector is pretty much stable. We have heard some of the large firms have high increases until after the election and then well see what happens after that.
So we dont see any declines, but obviously continued growth from other sectors and stability in the financial sector. If they are going to have a huge layoff then I think it will be sort of like we had last year, it will create some softening. But we dont see any signs of that coming yet.
In D.C. kind of similar story, but the lead there obviously is the federal government. We are renting to a lot of federal government employees, lot of contractors related to that, lot of lobbyists, lot of defense industry, but also a lot of lawyers, a lot of accountants, a lot of consulting firms, plus in D.C. area you have the health sciences, with HAS, a lot of biomedical healthcare health sciences. Youve got a lot of tech, lot high tech, and non-defense related technology.
So, D.C. is more than just the federal government, but clearly its the maintenance driver. If the federal government were able to actually accomplish some significant cuts it would be a setback. But as everybody knows usually talked a lot about and not actually accomplished.

componenttextpreview: We have no plans of doing joint ventures on acquisitions. Ill tell you we are talking about potentially doing a joint venture on one of our development transactions. But we have not talked with anyone about doing anything on the acquisition side. Just
componenttext: We have no plans of doing joint ventures on acquisitions. Ill tell you we are talking about potentially doing a joint venture on one of our development transactions. But we have not talked with anyone about doing anything on the acquisition side. Just to be clear Rob, the joint venture that was just terminated. It was done with an institutional investor with assets taken off our balance sheet 10 years ago and what have identified at that time as non-core markets. So, we had just retained a minor promoted interest in these assets and continue to manage them, but generally they were all of assets in markets that have been identified long ago as non-core assets.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The maintenance CapEx, so just lets flip to that page to make sure I understand which category youre in. So I think as we look at same store CapEx spend for the year, we think were going to roll up. Year-to-date, were at 322. We expect to be a
componenttext: The maintenance CapEx, so just lets flip to that page to make sure I understand which category youre in. So I think as we look at same store CapEx spend for the year, we think were going to roll up. Year-to-date, were at 322. We expect to be at 475, if you are talking about CapEx spend, building improvement spend, if thats what you mean by that. If you mean replacements, I would say, on the replacement side, we expect to be with our rehabs, give or take, $600, so we do think well add up rate around our $1,075 guidance number for CapEx.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Im sorry. Just to be clear, the 475 is building improvements. Thats the exterior stuff. Okay. When you talk about the replacements, we break those out for you. So we think about 600 in totality, about 250 a unit is rehabs and the rehabs, of course,
componenttext: Im sorry. Just to be clear, the 475 is building improvements. Thats the exterior stuff. Okay. When you talk about the replacements, we break those out for you. So we think about 600 in totality, about 250 a unit is rehabs and the rehabs, of course, are much more concentrated, but its hard for people to distinguish whether rehab is truly revenue creation or just value preservation, right? So you can look at that two ways. We tell you that 350 per unit without rehabs will spend on replacements. When you add rehabs in there, it gets to 600 total on replacements. So 600 on replacements, 475 on these exterior building improvements get you to 1,075.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one other one on that, is that given those sort of portfolio move over the last few years, away from the Sunbelt markets and into a lot of Northeastern and Mid-Atlantic assets, is the sort of concentration of your CapEx spend getting narrowe
componenttext: And then just one other one on that, is that given those sort of portfolio move over the last few years, away from the Sunbelt markets and into a lot of Northeastern and Mid-Atlantic assets, is the sort of concentration of your CapEx spend getting narrower and narrower in that sort of second, third quarter time period where the weather permits than it has historically?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we did do quite a bit in the third quarter. Im not sure that thats unusual for us. I guess as the markets end up being more Boston and New York, you will see a little bit more concentration there, but I mean, the third quarter has customarily
componenttext: Well, we did do quite a bit in the third quarter. Im not sure that thats unusual for us. I guess as the markets end up being more Boston and New York, you will see a little bit more concentration there, but I mean, the third quarter has customarily been a pretty big quarter for us on capital.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, guys.
componenttext: Okay, thanks, guys.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thank you. I was just wondering, it seems like your occupancy for October ticked down slightly and your occupancy from the third quarter to the second quarter ticked down slightly a little bit and I know there are some seasonality involved. But I was
componenttext: Hi, thank you. I was just wondering, it seems like your occupancy for October ticked down slightly and your occupancy from the third quarter to the second quarter ticked down slightly a little bit and I know there are some seasonality involved. But I was wondering if you were starting to see any resistance to pushing the rents on the renewals?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michelle, this is David Santee. Were really not seeing resistance on the renewals. David quoted some other rates that were seeing and as we move further into the year, we expect those types of rate increases to hold and improve in some markets. Like
componenttext: Michelle, this is David Santee. Were really not seeing resistance on the renewals. David quoted some other rates that were seeing and as we move further into the year, we expect those types of rate increases to hold and improve in some markets. Like you said, there is a natural seasonality to our business and the more that we get out of the Sunbelt, were more northern focused that seasonality becomes a little more pronounced. But I think that 10 basis point or 20 basis points that will recover here in the next couple of weeks.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just in terms of some of this markets where you may be close to peak or slightly above like New York and D.C., when you get back into the higher turn quarters next year or second quarter and third quarter, what kinds of rents do you think you can push at
componenttext: Just in terms of some of this markets where you may be close to peak or slightly above like New York and D.C., when you get back into the higher turn quarters next year or second quarter and third quarter, what kinds of rents do you think you can push at that point?

componenttext: Michelle, were not going into 2011 just yet. I can just tell you that the statistics of occupancy, retention renewal rates everything has been very strong to this point. Occupancy today is very strong and we feel very good about the way itll be setup going into the 2011.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Were looking at deals as I said, we got a pipeline and looking at some deals in Boston and D.C., in LA and San Francisco again there are in various levels stages of due diligence. There is no guarantee well close any of them. But weve got some assets and wed be happy to own it if they underwrite properly and if we can come to a meeting of the minds, this helps.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Given that you are seeing more product come to market right now. Do you think you will do more acquisitions next year like compared to this years level or do you think the acquisitions might - the pace might or the amount just might be a little bit less next year that you might do some more developments?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well again its hard to say what 2011 will bring and how much product would be made available and how aggressive our competitors will be with capital. I would tell this year had a $1.5 billion one of the reasons that we will get there is, we really did
componenttext: Well again its hard to say what 2011 will bring and how much product would be made available and how aggressive our competitors will be with capital. I would tell this year had a $1.5 billion one of the reasons that we will get there is, we really did see that flow of business right out of the blocks. Weve done $500 million very early in the year. But weve done that much in the past and we are certainly capable of doing more and its just hard to predict as to what the flow will be and what pricing will be and if we think it makes sense for us.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly do you think you could if you have the information give us. I know you gave us that total portfolio the rents were off about 5% from peak. Do you have some of your major markets how much they are off from peak?
componenttext: And then just lastly do you think you could if you have the information give us. I know you gave us that total portfolio the rents were off about 5% from peak. Do you have some of your major markets how much they are off from peak?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michelle, its Fred Tuomi. Relative to peak, as a general rule most markets peak back in the middle of 2008 on June or July. Those markets that have we right now that have actually established new peaks include South Florida, it was very good to see. So
componenttext:
Michelle, its Fred Tuomi. Relative to peak, as a general rule most markets peak back in the middle of 2008 on June or July. Those markets that have we right now that have actually established new peaks include South Florida, it was very good to see. South Florida was kind of flat for a long time and now its had a good steady run of sequential improvements in South Florida.
It established a new peak here in October. Boston, which has been a leader through the entire process has already established a new peak. Denver, Colorado, kind of the same story, good, steady, consistent growth establish a new peak, as well as D.C. on the Maryland side, Virginias close but not quite there yet.
And then on the flip side those furthest away that have the longest recapture to go yet is kind of not surprising on the west coast and specifically in the south west. So, there we have Phoenix, its still about 12% off, Santiago about 11% to go, Orange County about the same about 11% to 12% to go yet. And then Seattle is the leader in that respect, its got 15% or so to go before establishing a new peak.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks so much for the detail. Appreciate it.
componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks so much for the detail. Appreciate it.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. Is it possible for you guys to go into a little bit of detail, maybe choose one of your acquisitions that was done recently perhaps in San Francisco or D.C. and just walk us through some of the underwriting details relative to rent
componenttext: Just a quick question. Is it possible for you guys to go into a little bit of detail, maybe choose one of your acquisitions that was done recently perhaps in San Francisco or D.C. and just walk us through some of the underwriting details relative to rent growth for the next couple of years. Any changes to occupancy, how you think about the terminal value and your internal hurdles given that you framed the acquisition environment as competitive. I was just sort of curious as to how you think about these deals in a very specific example?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Without getting into any of these real specifics, Im not going to get down to that level of detail for you David. But I will tell you that in nearly any acquisition that were buying today at some point in the near future be it next year or the year
componenttext:
Without getting into any of these real specifics, Im not going to get down to that level of detail for you David. But I will tell you that in nearly any acquisition that were buying today at some point in the near future be it next year or the year after or the year after that. Im sure, weve got 4%, 5%, 6% increases. In the markets in which were buying with occupancy the way it is and single-family home situation, all of the things that were talking about, there is no doubt in my minds that we will see some very attractive rental rate growth going forward and improvements in revenue on the assets that weve been acquiring.
Like Ive been saying, weve been buying sort of high 4s, maybe, low 6s, we think were going to get into the high 6s and 7s in some of these fairly promptly. The IRRs weve been underwriting have been low 9s to maybe low 10s, and at what a price per door is today and what that terminal value price per door will be and that value compound average growth rate of that has been 3% or 4%. So, we think that the assumption weve been making have been very reasonable given whats going on out there just on the supply and demand fundamentals across our major markets.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the financing environment, do you assume a static financing environment at the time of the terminal value estimation?
componenttext: And then in terms of the financing environment, do you assume a static financing environment at the time of the terminal value estimation?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess we dont really make any assumptions or estimates about what we think the financing market will be at that time. We just look at whats historically in the markets, what deals have traded for on a cap rate basis and look at again, prices per d
componenttext: I guess we dont really make any assumptions or estimates about what we think the financing market will be at that time. We just look at whats historically in the markets, what deals have traded for on a cap rate basis and look at again, prices per door and prices per square foot and try and get comfortable as to what those terminal values would be.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my last question is just relative to price points. Have you seen any trends in the last couple of months relative to any kind of price point divergence relative to your more expensive apartments versus some of your sort of lower B quality apartme
componenttext: And then my last question is just relative to price points. Have you seen any trends in the last couple of months relative to any kind of price point divergence relative to your more expensive apartments versus some of your sort of lower B quality apartments?

componenttext: In terms of evaluations?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I dont have exact statistic for you, but I can just tell you anecdotally and what my sense is that the bigger tickets unit seems to be selling extremely well. As again I mentioned before at the New York just last week, and what they told me was there w
componenttext:
I dont have exact statistic for you, but I can just tell you anecdotally and what my sense is that the bigger tickets unit seems to be selling extremely well. As again I mentioned before at the New York just last week, and what they told me was there was actually a waiting list for some of our penthouse units. So our penthouse units which are at the entire floor, lots of premium rents added to them. Those units are full. In fact we have a waiting list at Trump for some combined units. Same is true in downtown Boston. The penthouse units leased extremely well during the leasing season and went down like may be one rep.
So the premium pricing which we add for premium units such as views, floors, other amenities has recovered fully in those markets. So I feel very good about the ability to rent at the high end. Some of the lease ups that David mentioned, for example, 425 Mass in D.C., thats an expensive building. Its a high rent district. Weve got very high-wage earning people living there and weve been able to rent those at a very fast pace. So, there doesnt seem to be price resistance at the higher level.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. David, you talked about the land parcels you acquired throughout the year and you are looking at more. I just wanted to get a sense of how is the market there, how the price is trending for the land pricing and what kind of competition you are seeing?
componenttext: Hi. David, you talked about the land parcels you acquired throughout the year and you are looking at more. I just wanted to get a sense of how is the market there, how the price is trending for the land pricing and what kind of competition you are seeing? Is that the same level of competition for the multi-family assets for the land?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I dont believe theres much competition for the land sites, but theres certainly is competition. Just anecdotally through conversations that Ive had with various people at National Multi Housing Council meetings and the recent ULI meetings, the
componenttext:
I dont believe theres much competition for the land sites, but theres certainly is competition. Just anecdotally through conversations that Ive had with various people at National Multi Housing Council meetings and the recent ULI meetings, there are awful lot of people that are working on trying to arrange capital to buy development parcels.
So, land prices have not recovered back to where they were by any stretch. Sellers were never giving it away when prices were very low, the levels that would only make sense for developers to pay, but there are land parcels being made available and theres certainly competition, but it would not compare to what you are seeing the level of competition for completed stabilized core assets.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned a handful of deals for the reminder of the year. Can you tell us if these are sort the stabilized type deals or are more newer sort of construction and condo conversion type assets?
componenttext: You mentioned a handful of deals for the reminder of the year. Can you tell us if these are sort the stabilized type deals or are more newer sort of construction and condo conversion type assets?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well what we have in the pipeline today does not include anything that would be similar to the Vantage Pointe or the 425 Mass Avenue transaction. Thats not because we have not underwritten them, we have looked at some and we have just havent come to
componenttext: Well what we have in the pipeline today does not include anything that would be similar to the Vantage Pointe or the 425 Mass Avenue transaction. Thats not because we have not underwritten them, we have looked at some and we have just havent come to meeting the minds with the seller and frankly I would like to do more of those. I think that we have established a real core competency in leasing these things up, and I would be delighted to have more opportunities. But even for those types of property I would tell you there is competition out there for those.

componenttext: Just giving you a frame of reference. We were down 12 and giving you a frame of reference about where we are relative to some point in time. componenttext: You gave the renewal statistics over 5% in last few months. What is the kind of the unit-over unit new lease change? I know you gave the 8.7% asking rents at the beginning of the year, but on equivalent basis to your renewal increases, whats the new lease number?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I assume youre asking about kind of a replacement rent? Yes and we do have those numbers. Those gets a little mix peak because it depends on when someone moves out, how long is it vacant, before someone moves back in, what unit type is it, were they
componenttext: I assume youre asking about kind of a replacement rent? Yes and we do have those numbers. Those gets a little mix peak because it depends on when someone moves out, how long is it vacant, before someone moves back in, what unit type is it, were theyre coming from a three-month lease going to a 12-month lease or vice versa. Theres a lot of noise and chatter on that. Its not a clear 12-month, the next day kind of thing. But overall portfolio wide, were up about 2.5% to 3% gain on the total mix of our replacement rents and it will vary by market and actually by property and by day of the week.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the question on the household formation, when you said the 800,000 to 900,000 new household this year. Where are they coming from, is that the unbundling thing or is there more to it than that in your minds?
componenttext: And then the question on the household formation, when you said the 800,000 to 900,000 new household this year. Where are they coming from, is that the unbundling thing or is there more to it than that in your minds?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there is a lot more to it and that youve got this demographic fact of this echo-boom generation, how many kids graduate from college, you got immigration, you got all sorts of things. I would not suggest that it was purely unbundling, but we wo
componenttext: I think there is a lot more to it and that youve got this demographic fact of this echo-boom generation, how many kids graduate from college, you got immigration, you got all sorts of things. I would not suggest that it was purely unbundling, but we would expect that there will be some of that. We do see some of that in our own portfolio as we see our own residence unbundled. So, I think that step was certainly part of it, but as to what sort of markets share unbundling represents I couldnt begin to tell you that.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: 1.2 that you referenced, what do you think you need to get sustain the great things that are going on in the space right now in terms of household formation?
componenttext: 1.2 that you referenced, what do you think you need to get sustain the great things that are going on in the space right now in terms of household formation?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I dont know the exact answer for that question, but Ill tell you that historically in apartment kind of recovery you relied on household growth and job growth to sort of reestablish occupancy that had been lost during the downturn. But we ne
componenttext:
I guess I dont know the exact answer for that question, but Ill tell you that historically in apartment kind of recovery you relied on household growth and job growth to sort of reestablish occupancy that had been lost during the downturn. But we never really lost much occupancy during the downturn and so, were going into this recovery well occupied and thats why you are seeing strong retention rents and strong increases in our asking rents.
I just think that if we get another 800,000 or 900,000 households the next year, I suppose which is possible seeing how thats what happened last year and this year even with our job growth, I think well be in a point where we continue to see really strong fundamentals. If you add job growth on to that and get household growth back to that 1.2 million level with no new supply being added it only gets better.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question on acquisitions. Part of the problem that happened in the sort of 05, 06 timeframe people were buying assets at very low cap rates on the belief that there will be growth in that math obviously it did not work out, ultimately somebody
componenttext: Last question on acquisitions. Part of the problem that happened in the sort of 05, 06 timeframe people were buying assets at very low cap rates on the belief that there will be growth in that math obviously it did not work out, ultimately somebody was left holding the bag. The same thing is happening now. Can you tell why we shouldnt be worried to some degree that the low cap rates that youre buying at are presuming some substantial increase in rent and if that doesnt materialize then are we setting ourselves up for a similar sort of outcome?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I guess just thinking about where weve been buying and where rents were and where rents are today and looking at whats going on in the whole single-family home side. Look, I mean we worry about everything everyday here. I cant tell you that
componenttext: Well I guess just thinking about where weve been buying and where rents were and where rents are today and looking at whats going on in the whole single-family home side. Look, I mean we worry about everything everyday here. I cant tell you that we dont worry about anything, but I just look at what prices we are paying, per door, per unit and the yields were getting, frankly, the yields which were selling our assets, we are happy with the trend.

componenttext: I just want to go back to the developments for a minute. Just want to get your thoughts on a few things here. One is if high-rise is on your list or if you consider high-rise something thats better to buy rather than develop and then as you do this next round, should we expect most of this will be done in-house or are you going to be contracting with third parties to do the development and then you take over the deal at completion?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: I will not say that we will not do joint ventures, but we have our own extremely experienced, extremely capable in-house development team and well be looking to that group to provide most of our opportunity, mostly what we are doing sort of mid-rise product. We do not have any high-rise product kind of in the works today, so again, that will mostly be mid-rise and some garden and wrap product. But we will be doing that mostly ourselves and my guess is mostly itll be sort of a smaller total cost projects than what youve seen us start back in three or four years ago.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the debt side, looking to your maturities next year and obviously now given where we are in year, better sense of what rates might be? The term loan gets pushed I guess into 12, you only have it looks like very little unsecured. So Im guessing th
componenttext: On the debt side, looking to your maturities next year and obviously now given where we are in year, better sense of what rates might be? The term loan gets pushed I guess into 12, you only have it looks like very little unsecured. So Im guessing the rest is mortgage. What should we be thinking about for you guys, refinancing your stuff for next year and obviously some of that will be paid off with disposition proceeds?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its a great conversation you and I have every call. I think we are positioned well for 2011 maturities. Theyre mostly in May and August. There is a big unsecured maturity. Our convertible debt comes due in August. Really, theres a put and a call
componenttext:
Its a great conversation you and I have every call. I think we are positioned well for 2011 maturities. Theyre mostly in May and August. There is a big unsecured maturity. Our convertible debt comes due in August. Really, theres a put and a call and effectively comes due in August 2011. So I do think of that as a maturity and its reflected as such. So I wanted to mention that. I think we have a bias towards the unsecured market. I think the unsecured that maybe a 4.3% or 4.4% tenure on secured rates. Its a terrific place to finance this company. The secured debt rate is probably a little bit lower but not much.
So I guess as you think about replacement rates, I think its a good chance that we hope to get underneath that rate. We give a totaled fixed rate right now of 5.43% for 2011, and the bogie that we have out there for me and for our treasurer is to get to below that number. So that interest expense is accretive. We are able to do that on the July issuance at the 5.09% issuance. I feel very optimistic about that. Weve got some hedges in place as well if rates move up I feel very optimistic about that. Weve got some hedges in place as well if rates move up. So, I feel good about how we are positioned going into 2011.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Mark, the convert, I think of differently rather than straight unsecured, but if we just got up the numbers, is the balance all mortgage? There is about 500 or so of convert. There is the term loan, which is another 500, well thats 12 I sho
componenttext: And then Mark, the convert, I think of differently rather than straight unsecured, but if we just got up the numbers, is the balance all mortgage? There is about 500 or so of convert. There is the term loan, which is another 500, well thats 12 I should say, thats 95 of straight unsecured. Is the balance of everything else just regular mortgage debt?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Is that tax exempt or is it all just straight like Fannie, Freddie type stuff?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Correct, the latter. There is both pools and one-offs in there that need to be refinanced.

componenttext: Okay. Then just a final question is the other expense guidance of 11 to 12, does that include Prospect Towers or Prospect Towers is separate from that?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Prospect Towers cost dont run through that line item. if you go to the P&L, theyre going to run through property, tax and insurance line item. So there is real estate taxes and insurance. So, the $3.5 million thats on the non-comp schedule for Pr
componenttext: Prospect Towers cost dont run through that line item. if you go to the P&L, theyre going to run through property, tax and insurance line item. So there is real estate taxes and insurance. So, the $3.5 million thats on the non-comp schedule for Prospect Towers, they run through that line item. The $835,000 of less revenue that we talk about for Prospect Towers for the quarter, Alex, that runs through rental income. So, rental income is $835,000 lower this quarter because of Prospect Towers and real estate taxes and insurance are $3.5 million higher this quarter because of Prospect Towers.

componenttext: So, the other expense, the other whatever is $3 million or so whatever the number is, in the fourth quarter thats separate and apart, thats the point.

componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. On expense growth, I know you guys have been pretty good there for some time. As you look out to next year, and Ill take a stab at this, but you mentioned real estate taxes down, I assume that favorable benefit will carry in
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. On expense growth, I know you guys have been pretty good there for some time. As you look out to next year, and Ill take a stab at this, but you mentioned real estate taxes down, I assume that favorable benefit will carry into next year. In payroll, youve seen some increases here due to the bonuses, but I am just curious as you think about expense growth next year, are you expecting to maintain sort of that 1.5% range or are there some factors we should think about that would push you one direction or the other?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: All the municipalities have been hesitant to raise rates and very quick to lower valuations and theyre being supported by the stimulus funds. We really havent heard whats going to happen next year, I mean if some of these states do what they need
componenttext: All the municipalities have been hesitant to raise rates and very quick to lower valuations and theyre being supported by the stimulus funds. We really havent heard whats going to happen next year, I mean if some of these states do what they need to do, we could probably expect some increase in rates next year. But that will remain to be seen until next year. On the payroll, I feel very good about being able to maintain consistent, predictable, expense management for quite some time.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, you mentioned starts next year, just switching to development of $340 million, is that a level you would think could move up over time? Is that level what you think to maintain as you look out to say 11 and 12 at $340 million per annum?
componenttext: David, you mentioned starts next year, just switching to development of $340 million, is that a level you would think could move up over time? Is that level what you think to maintain as you look out to say 11 and 12 at $340 million per annum?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again its hard to say. Id just tell you that of the assets that weve acquired this year that could start in 2011. Those starts would total $340 million. If weve started anything of our sort of legacy land inventory, obviously that number would
componenttext: Again its hard to say. Id just tell you that of the assets that weve acquired this year that could start in 2011. Those starts would total $340 million. If weve started anything of our sort of legacy land inventory, obviously that number would go up. We did have at one-time about a $500 million sort of a year start run rate in development, and I suppose we could see that again, but its just going to depend on if we see the appropriate opportunities relative to what we can actually buy in those markets.

componenttext: We really dont measure that. I mean LRO gives you 16 weeks of pricing all of which are different, so I would have to pick up a week to measure that. So we dont really look at loss to lease any longer.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You have made a number of investments here in D.C. in the third quarter as well as year-to-date. It has moved now past peak rents, and you are also starting to see some development. I am just curious how you feel about D.C. going forward relative to the p
componenttext: You have made a number of investments here in D.C. in the third quarter as well as year-to-date. It has moved now past peak rents, and you are also starting to see some development. I am just curious how you feel about D.C. going forward relative to the potential supply concerns and whether thats still a market that makes sense to buy as opposed to build at this point?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of just the performance of the market, Im still very optimistic and very bullish on the D.C. markets. I mean, rents are up double-digit year-to-date, 10% year-over-year. Were getting 5.5% to 6% renewal increases, occupancies are solid, rent
componenttext:
In terms of just the performance of the market, Im still very optimistic and very bullish on the D.C. markets. I mean, rents are up double-digit year-to-date, 10% year-over-year. Were getting 5.5% to 6% renewal increases, occupancies are solid, rent to lease is manageable. Its just all good things. I dont see anything really going to change that. In terms of the supply demand, its had a lot of supply brought in over the last three years running, right through the downturn. Weve had 7,000 units back in 08, 7,600 in 09, 4,800 units delivered this year at the worst possible time, but yet weve had some of the best fundamentals.
The reason is D.C. as a general market had record apartment absorption over the last two years, which is really mind blowing, but when you look at it, it was just fortunate timing with the fantastic job creation from the whole Federal government and all the other aspects I talked about earlier. Right now in 2011, there will be some continued development but only 1,400 units being delivered in entire D.C., Virginia, Maryland market. So thats a significant reduction. I dont see a slowdown in demand, but its likely to come at some point, it will moderate, but with only 1,400 units coming in, youll feel very good about 2011 and early into 2012. We, as well as other people are talking about development in D.C..
When you talk to anybody about development, D.C. is one of the things they talk about. So I do expect some more units to be delivered there in maybe late 11, 12, 13, but will it be back up to 7,000-8,000 units? I dont think so. That would take a lot of return at a merchant builders and lot of lending to support that. I think its going to be well capitalized, more disciplined, folks going to be adding units. So, there will be some supply coming back, but Ill think its going to be disrupted.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Finally, just as you start to look at development, you acquired a number of parcels during the quarter. What level of development should we be looking for from EQR going forward, whats the level that you feel comfortable kind of running at? Obviously,
componenttext: Finally, just as you start to look at development, you acquired a number of parcels during the quarter. What level of development should we be looking for from EQR going forward, whats the level that you feel comfortable kind of running at? Obviously, youve run down the portfolio here over there in the past couple of years just through completions and lease up. Just kind of wondering what we should expect kind of the long-term development strategy is there?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as I just answered, we can start $340 million in 2011 if we just only start those deals that weve acquired this year that we believe in a position to start construction next year. We have in the past had sort of historical run rate of as much as
componenttext: Well, as I just answered, we can start $340 million in 2011 if we just only start those deals that weve acquired this year that we believe in a position to start construction next year. We have in the past had sort of historical run rate of as much as $500 million or so of starts. So, I guess we have the capacity both with capital and internal capacity of our development team to do $500 million a year. Its just going to be a function of will there be sufficient opportunities, priced accordingly relative to acquisition opportunities. So, its very hard to tell you, to say Mike, what that will be going forward.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe, Ill just put in different ways. Whats the preference right now as to buy versus build? Are you moving more towards development at this point or do you still feel that acquisitions make the most sense?
componenttext: Maybe, Ill just put in different ways. Whats the preference right now as to buy versus build? Are you moving more towards development at this point or do you still feel that acquisitions make the most sense?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, its a market-by-market, opportunity-by-opportunity decision that we make. Frankly, we have been buying in every single market that weve been buying existing assets in every single market in which weve been buying development sites. So, the
componenttext: Again, its a market-by-market, opportunity-by-opportunity decision that we make. Frankly, we have been buying in every single market that weve been buying existing assets in every single market in which weve been buying development sites. So, there have been limited opportunities in these markets and so weve been buying and buying existing deals and buying land sites. So, its not always a either or proposition as long as youre getting the appropriate risk adjusted premium for taking on all the risks of the development. So, right now in every core market in which we operate, were considering both.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys.
componenttext: Thanks, guys.

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Dustin Pizzo of UBS.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, good afternoon, guys.
componenttext: Hey, good afternoon, guys.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, Dustin.
componenttext: Hey, Dustin.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not to beat the dead horse around the rental rate growth, but just following up on I think what Richs earlier question related to the rents, you were all concerned your ability to continue to push the rent at the same momentum if we dont see inco
componenttext: Not to beat the dead horse around the rental rate growth, but just following up on I think what Richs earlier question related to the rents, you were all concerned your ability to continue to push the rent at the same momentum if we dont see income growth just given that ratio is already back to long-term average or do you simply think that people are going to willing to pay more rents or more on rent going forward or I guess just quite frankly have to pay more on rent going forward given the supply demand dynamics?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think its more the lateral, I think they have to. I think we remained very confident just looking at supply demand and all the things weve talked about that rents are going up. Its just a question of how much rents are going up. Clearly, wed
componenttext:
I think its more the lateral, I think they have to. I think we remained very confident just looking at supply demand and all the things weve talked about that rents are going up. Its just a question of how much rents are going up. Clearly, wed like job growth because we think with that there will be more household formation, rents will go up more.
But we think that just at 95% occupancy with all the things weve talked about, we focus a lot on unfortunate 9% of the population that are unemployed and we got 91% of the population that is employed and those people are hunkering down they are in our units, theyre indicating to us that they have no intention of leaving certainly not at the rates that they had in the past. So, we see no reason why we cant continue to get very good rental increases from that subset.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe I understood or misunderstood, but in your opening comments you talked about getting stabilized seven plus yield in three years at Vantage Pointe on current rents. So, just to be clear is that not assume any increase in rents over the next
componenttext: And then maybe I understood or misunderstood, but in your opening comments you talked about getting stabilized seven plus yield in three years at Vantage Pointe on current rents. So, just to be clear is that not assume any increase in rents over the next three years?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Those yields that I gave to you there and the yields I gave you on the development deals are based upon rents that are currently in the marketplace. Any subsequent rental increases in the market will only improve those returns.
componenttext: Those yields that I gave to you there and the yields I gave you on the development deals are based upon rents that are currently in the marketplace. Any subsequent rental increases in the market will only improve those returns.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, good morning. Just a couple of questions and maybe one follow-up to Dustins question. David, you said people will have to pay a larger percent of their income to ramp, one, I just double backup if could get a whack [ph]?
componenttext: Hey, good morning. Just a couple of questions and maybe one follow-up to Dustins question. David, you said people will have to pay a larger percent of their income to ramp, one, I just double backup if could get a whack [ph]?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Suppose at some point that could happen, but I again I think we are just seeing incremental sort of demand in this system even without a lot of job growth that probably should offset that or certainly could offset that. Im not suggesting that we don
componenttext: Suppose at some point that could happen, but I again I think we are just seeing incremental sort of demand in this system even without a lot of job growth that probably should offset that or certainly could offset that. Im not suggesting that we dont worry about this stuff, I think we do. We all wonder how long we can continue to push rents and wait the rate that we have. But we continue to push as long as our guests who tell us that we can, and again when you are 95% occupied at, on November 1 thats a pretty good place so roll into the next years leasing season. I cant tell you if rents are going up 2%, 4% or 6%, but we are very confident that they are going up and if we just get job growth it well just go up one.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on development, can you comment on what construction cost has done may be peak to trough and then whether you are seeing any pressure and if you can may be stick to some of your various components that would be great?
componenttext: And then on development, can you comment on what construction cost has done may be peak to trough and then whether you are seeing any pressure and if you can may be stick to some of your various components that would be great?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Im not equipped to sort of go through a whole lot of the components but I would tell you that we think construction cost may be were down 20 or so percent, 20% to 25% we still think they are down 15% to 20% from peak. So, that we think at leas
componenttext: Well, Im not equipped to sort of go through a whole lot of the components but I would tell you that we think construction cost may be were down 20 or so percent, 20% to 25% we still think they are down 15% to 20% from peak. So, that we think at least relative to our construction cost have been its still in attractive level, but just in terms of the different components I cant go into that level of detail for you.

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: One last question. It seems like the end of last year the buyer pool on acquisitions fell dramatically once deal got over say $50 million or $75 million which doesnt seem to be the case anymore. Where you think that breakpoint is today where that the b
componenttext: One last question. It seems like the end of last year the buyer pool on acquisitions fell dramatically once deal got over say $50 million or $75 million which doesnt seem to be the case anymore. Where you think that breakpoint is today where that the buyer pool starts to materially spend out?

headline: Equity Residential, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thats a good question. I am not sure where that breakpoint is frankly. I mean theres just a lot of institutional demand for property, and I think what you had seen before Andy, a year or so ago late last year, where price point that were low and eas
componenttext: Thats a good question. I am not sure where that breakpoint is frankly. I mean theres just a lot of institutional demand for property, and I think what you had seen before Andy, a year or so ago late last year, where price point that were low and easily financeable by Freddie and Fannie and required an equity component that was rather manageable. Now that the institutional capital was off the sidelines I think sort of all bets are off. Theres just a significant amount of institutional money out there looking for assets, and names that weve not seen in a long time, foreign investors that had not been active. Im not quite sure I know where that break is today.

componenttext: Well before I answer that specific question. Let me just tell you that in any given year we will always have assets that we believe that we want to sell. But I think weve got $1.5 billion of products that weve identified today that we think are sort of non-strategic, non-core assets that weve like to sell over some time in the next year or so.

componenttext: Typically, were quoting about 80 to 100 basis points higher than what we achieved. As I said thats a pretty good run rate. Looking out, were quoting seven and achieving six out here in November, as David has mentioned, but typically 80 to 100 basis points.
